case_name: Gordon Woodroffee Leather Manufacturing Company Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 62 of 1961 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 62 of 1961. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated December 20, 1956 of Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 85 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 20, 1956, of the Madras High Court in Case Referred No. 85 of 1953.

facts.text: Appellant is the assessee, respondent is Commissioner of Income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the assessee and the respondent is the Commissioner of Income-tax and the question raised is as to applicability of s. 10 2  xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act

facts.text: Appeal relates to assessment year 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal relates to the assessment year 1950-51. M s. Gordon Woodroffee Co.  Madras  Ltd., was incorporated

facts.text: Ms. Gordon Woodroffe Co. Madras Ltd. incorporated as private limited company in 1922.

anchor.surface_text: M s. Gordon Woodroffee Co.  Madras  Ltd., was incorporated as a private limited companypany in 1922 and became the Managing Agent

facts.text: Ms. Gordon Woodroffe Co. Madras Ltd. became Managing Agent of appellant company.

anchor.surface_text: in 1922 and became the Managing Agent of a public limited companypany M s. Gordon Woodroffee Leather Manufacturing Company Ltd., which is the assessee.

facts.text: J.H. Philips was employee in Managing Agent Company from 1922 to 1935.

anchor.surface_text: One J. H. Philips was employee in the Managing Agent Company from 1922 to 1935 and from 1935 he became an employee of the appellant companypany

facts.text: J.H. Philips became employee of appellant company from 1935 and Director from 1940.

anchor.surface_text: and from 1935 he became an employee of the appellant companypany and became its Director from 1940.

facts.text: On March 22, 1949, J.H. Philips wrote letter expressing intention to resign from Board as from April 4, 1949 upon retirement.

anchor.surface_text: On March 22, 1949, he wrote a letter to the appellant companypany expressing his intention to resign from the Board of the Company as from April 4, 1949 upon his retirement from the employment of the companypany

facts.text: On March 24, 1949, Board of Directors passed resolution accepting resignation and paying gratuity of Rs. 50,000 (company Rs.40,000, Managing Agent Rs.10,000).

anchor.surface_text: On March 24, 1949, the Board of Directors of the appellant Company passed a resolution that his resignation be accepted and in appreciation of his long and valuable services to Company hebe paid a gratuity of Rs. 50,000/- out of which the appellant Company was to pay Rs. 40,000/- and the Managing Agent Company the balance of Rs. 10,000/-

facts.text: On April 4, 1949, Board resolution was confirmed.

anchor.surface_text: April 4, 1949, this resolution of the Board of Directors was companyfirmed.

facts.text: On April 4, 1949, Extraordinary General Meeting passed resolution to same effect.

anchor.surface_text: On the same date a resolution to the same effect was passed at an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Company

facts.text: Before end of accounting year October 31, 1949, Rs.40,000 paid to J.H. Philips.

anchor.surface_text: and before the end of its accounting year i. e. October 31, 1949, this amount of Rs. 40,000/- was paid to Mr. J. H. Philips.

facts.text: Amount claimed as deduction under s.10(2)(xv) of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: This amount was claimed as a deduction under s. 10  2  xv  of the Income-tax Act which reads - Section 10  2  Such profits or gains shall be companyputed

facts.text: Income-tax Officer disallowed the amount.

anchor.surface_text: The amount was disallowed by the Income-tax Officer as well as by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld disallowance.

anchor.surface_text: as well as by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on the ground that the appellant Company had numberpension scheme the payment was voluntary

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld the order.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the appellant Company took an appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal which upheld the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: Tribunal held no pension scheme, payment voluntary, debited to appropriation account.

anchor.surface_text: It held that according to the resolution the gratuity was paid for long and valuable services to the Company that there was numberhing to indicate that Mr. J. H. Philips had accepted a lower salary in expectation of getting a gratuity

facts.text: Case referred to High Court under s.66(1), question on deductibility of Rs.40,000.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant Company the case was stated to the High Court under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act and the following question was referred - Whether the sum of Rs. 40,000/- paid to Mr. J. H. Philips

facts.text: High Court answered question against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question against the appellant Company.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: Against this judgment and order the appellant Company has brought this appeal by special leave.

facts.text: No practice in company to pay such gratuities.

anchor.surface_text: There was numberpractice in the appellant companypany to pay such amounts and it did number affect the quantum of salary of the recipient.
s. 10 2  xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act to a gratuity paid by the appellant to one of its officers on his retirement from service.

concepts.unlisted_description: Deduction for any expenditure (not capital or personal) laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of business, profession or vocation.

anchor.surface_text: This amount was claimed as a deduction under s. 10  2  xv  of the Income-tax Act which reads - Section 10 2  Such profits or gains shall be companyputed after making the following allowances, namely any expenditure  number being an allowance of the nature described in any of the claused  i  to  xiv  inclusive, and number being in the nature of capital expenditure or personal expenses of the assesee  laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of such business, profession or vocation.

anchor.surface_text: under s. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act and the following question was referred - Whether the sum of Rs. 40,000/- paid to Mr. J. H. Philips

concepts.unlisted_description: Reference of case to High Court at instance of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the sum of Rs. 40,000/- paid to Mr. J. H. Philips on his retirement from the service of the Company was number an admissible deduction under Section 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

concepts.unlisted_description: Deduction for any expenditure (not capital or personal) laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of business, profession or vocation.

concepts.interpretation: Payment does not qualify as it was voluntary recognition of past services, not pursuant to any scheme, no employee expectation, no practice affecting salary, not for commercial expediency or to facilitate business.
concepts.unlisted_description: Deduction for any expenditure (not capital or personal) laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of business, profession or vocation.

anchor.surface_text: satisfy the requirements of Section 10 2  xv , even if those requirements are judged from the view point of companymercial expediency, as it always should be when a claim arises under Section 10 2  xv .

concepts.interpretation: Requirements of s.10(2)(xv) to be judged from viewpoint of commercial expediency; mere recognition of past services insufficient.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: exclusively for the purpose of the business of the Company. These tests the assessee did number satisfy in this case. Against this judgment and order

concepts.unlisted_description: Test for whether expenditure serves the business purposes under income tax deduction provisions.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the proper test to apply in this case is, was the payment made as a matter of practice which affected the quantum of salary or was there an expectation by the employee of getting a gratuity or was the sum of money expended on the ground of companymercial expediency and in order indirectly to facilitate the carrying on of the business.

concepts.interpretation: Proper test for deductibility of gratuity: (1) made as matter of practice affecting quantum of salary; or (2) expectation by employee; or (3) expended on ground of commercial expediency to indirectly facilitate carrying on of business.
concepts.unlisted_description: Multi-factor test for allowing gratuity as revenue expenditure under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: and number being in the nature of capital expenditure or personal expenses of the assesee  laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of such business, profession or vocation.

concepts.interpretation: Expenditure in nature of capital expense not deductible; here, debited to appropriation account indicating capital nature.

concepts.unlisted_description: High Court tests for commercial expediency in gratuity payment deductibility.

issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 40,000/- paid to Mr. J. H. Philips on his retirement from the service of the Company was an admissible deduction under Section 10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the sum of Rs. 40,000/- paid to Mr. J. H. Philips on his retirement from the service of the Company was number an admissible deduction under Section 10 2  xv  of the Income-tax Act, 1922.

issues.text: the question raised is as to applicability of s. 10(2)(xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act to a gratuity paid by the appellant to one of its officers on his retirement from service.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent is the Commissioner of Income-tax and the question raised is as to applicability of s. 10 2  xv  of the Indian Income-tax Act to a gratuity paid by the appellant to one of its officers on his retirement from service.

issues.text: Was the expenditure incurred in the future interest of the business of the assessee? Was there any connection between the purpose of the payment and the further conduct of the business of the assessee?

anchor.surface_text: Was the expenditure incurred in the future interest of the business of the assessee? Was there any connection between the purpose of the payment and the further conduct of the business of the assessee ? These are the tests to be satisfied before it companyld be said that in paying the gratuity money was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the business of the Company.

issues.text: was the payment made as a matter of practice which affected the quantum of salary or was there an expectation by the employee of getting a gratuity or was the sum of money expended on the ground of commercial expediency and in order indirectly to facilitate the carrying on of the business.

arguments.claim: Rs. 40,000 gratuity payment is deductible under s.10(2)(xv) of the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: This amount was claimed as a deduction under s. 10  2  xv  of the Income-tax Act which reads - Section 10  2  Such profits or gains shall be companyputed

arguments.court_reasoning: Payment voluntary recognition of past services, not pursuant to any scheme of gratuities, no employee expectation, no practice affecting salary, not for commercial expediency

arguments.claim: Payment not deductible as voluntary with no pension scheme and indicated as capital payment by book entry

anchor.surface_text: The amount was disallowed by the Income-tax Officer as well as by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on the ground that the appellant Company had numberpension scheme the payment was voluntary

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court accepts factual findings on voluntary nature and book entry

arguments.claim: Gratuity for past services only, no salary reduction in expectation, no company practice, no recompense expectancy, debited to appropriation account indicating capital, not wholly for business

anchor.surface_text: It held that according to the resolution the gratuity was paid for long and valuable services to the Company that there was numberhing to indicate that Mr. J. H. Philips had accepted a lower salary in expectation of getting a gratuity

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court relies on these findings

arguments.claim: Amount must be laid out wholly and exclusively for business purposes under s.10(2)(xv); voluntary payment for past services lacks evidence of employee expectation or company contemplation, no future business interest

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question against the appellant Company. It held that in order that s. 10 2   xv  be applicable it had to be proved that the amount was laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for purposes of the companypanys business.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court agrees payment not for business purposes

arguments.claim: Recognition of past services alone insufficient for s.10(2)(xv) even under commercial expediency; requires future business interest and connection to further business conduct

anchor.surface_text: In the case of a payment of a gratuity to a retiring employee recognition of his past services, with numberhing more cannot, in our opinion satisfy the requirements of Section 10 2  xv , even if those requirements are judged from the view point of companymercial expediency,

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court adopts similar multi-factor test for deductibility

arguments.claim: Payment made as commercial expediency and company interest to induce other employees for efficient honest service, likely future payments as incentive, commercial prudence, good faith no oblique motive

anchor.surface_text: It was argued on behalf of the appellant that the amount had been paid as a matter of companymercial expediency and in the interest of the Company as an inducement to other employees that if they rendered service in a similar manner with efficiency and honesty they would be similarly rewarded.

arguments.court_reasoning: No supporting facts: no scheme, no recipient expectation, no practice, no salary impact, mere past service recognition

arguments.claim: Cases of Hancock and Smith support deductibility of similar gratuity/pension payments

anchor.surface_text: The two cases strongly relied upon by the appellant Company were J. P. Hancok v. General Reversionary Investment Company Ltd. 1  and J. W. Smith v. The Incorporated Council of Law Reporting for England and Wales 2 .

arguments.court_reasoning: Distinguished as those cases involved established practice known to employees affecting salary quantum

arguments.claim: Payment does not qualify under s.10(2)(xv) as not pursuant to gratuity scheme, no recipient expectation for service, voluntary recognition of past service, no business facilitation or expediency, no payment practice, no salary quantum effect

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion on the findings as given the payment in dispute does number fall within the provisions of s. 10 2  xv . The amount was paid number in pursuance of any scheme of payment of gratuities number was it an amount which the recipient expected to be paid for long and faithful service but it was voluntary payment

arguments.claim: Hancock case distinguishable as it involved company practice of pensions known to employees affecting salary rates
Proper test for deductibility: payment as practice affecting salary quantum, or employee expectation of gratuity, or expended for commercial expediency to indirectly facilitate business

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the proper test to apply in this case is, was the payment made as a matter of practice which affected the quantum of salary or was there an expectation by the employee of getting a gratuity or was the sum of money expended on the ground of companymercial expediency and in order indirectly to facilitate the carrying on of the business.

holdings.text: the payment in dispute does not fall within the provisions of s. 10(2)(xv)

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion on the findings as given the payment in dispute does number fall within the provisions of s. 10 2  xv . The amount was paid number in pursuance of any scheme of payment of gratuities number was it an amount which the recipient expected to be paid for long and faithful service but it was voluntary payment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on factual findings of no gratuity scheme, no employee expectation, voluntary nature as recognition of past services only, no practice affecting salary quantum

holdings.text: The amount was paid not in pursuance of any scheme of payment of gratuities nor was it an amount which the recipient expected to be paid for long and faithful service but it was voluntary payment not with the object of facilitating the carrying on of the business of the appellant Company or as a matter of commercial expediency but in recognition of long and faithful service of Mr. J. H. Philips

anchor.surface_text: The amount was paid number in pursuance of any scheme of payment of gratuities number was it an amount which the recipient expected to be paid for long and faithful service but it was voluntary payment number with the object of facilitating the carrying on of the business of the appellant Company or as a matter of companymercial expediency but in recognition of long and faithful service of Mr. J. H. Philips.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.10(2)(xv) requirement of expenditure wholly and exclusively for business purposes; mere past service recognition insufficient

holdings.text: There was no practice in the appellant company to pay such amounts and it did not affect the quantum of salary of the recipient

anchor.surface_text: There was numberpractice in the appellant companypany to pay such amounts and it did number affect the quantum of salary of the recipient.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts Tribunal and High Court findings on absence of practice or salary impact as factual basis for non-deductibility

holdings.text: In the Hancock case... it was the practice of the assessee company to grant pensions to its servants after a considerable period of service and this practice was known to the employees and affected the rate of salary paid by the Company
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Hancock precedent due to presence of established practice affecting salary, absent here

holdings.text: In the Smith case there was a practice of granting gratuities and that was the ground for holding the amount to be a proper deduction

anchor.surface_text: In the latter case there was a practice of granting gratuities and that was the ground for holding the amount to be a proper deduction.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Smith precedent based on existence of gratuity practice, unlike present case

holdings.text: the proper test to apply in this case is, was the payment made as a matter of practice which affected the quantum of salary or was there an expectation by the employee of getting a gratuity or was the sum of money expended on the ground of commercial expediency and in order indirectly to facilitate the carrying on of the business

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the proper test to apply in this case is, was the payment made as a matter of practice which affected the quantum of salary or was there an expectation by the employee of getting a gratuity or was the sum of money expended on the ground of companymercial expediency and in order indirectly to facilitate the carrying on of the business.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Formulates multi-factor test for deductibility of gratuity payments under s.10(2)(xv): practice affecting salary, employee expectation, or commercial expediency for business facilitation; none satisfied here
